Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: CEDAR: Identifying Sources of Mid-latitude Traveling Ionospheric Disturbances
Award.AbstractNarration:
Gravity waves (GWs) originating from lower atmospheric sources can lead to large accelerations of the background flow through wave dissipation or breaking. The accelerations produce secondary GWs with longer wavelengths, allowing them to propagate farther upward into the ionosphere. Here, through interaction with the ionospheric plasma, they are visible in the form of optical signatures in red line (630 nm) images, and are often referred to as traveling ionospheric disturbances (TIDs).
A broad array of optical imagers will be used to triangulate the lower atmospheric sources for F region GWs, quantifying the GWs by numerically modeling the same optical signatures, and then using this quantification to ray-trace the secondary GWs to reveal their altitude profile of momentum deposition. This effort will connect two critical points on the coupled path: from the lower atmospheric source to momentum deposition in the mid to upper thermosphere.
This project will include outreach to students at rural high schools where the instruments will be deployed. It will also provide undergraduate students opportunities to participate in data analysis and interpretation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project studies waves and disturbances that propagate large distances in the earth's upper atmosphere and traces their origins to the lower atmospheric or magnetospheric sources using a network of airglow imagers called the Midl-atitude All-sky Imager Network for Geophysical Observations (MANGO). Airglow is typically produced when ions and electrons in the earth?s ionized upper atmosphere recombine. The MANGO network studies nighttime airglow, which is a generally uniform background, and any enhancement or depletion in intensity can be detected using low-light, sensitive, science-grade cameras. The MANGO network was implemented as conceived in the proposal. It is operating continuously across the continental United States and producing data. Major activities have been data acquisition and analysis, providing data to modeling groups working on coupling of lower atmosphere and the ionosphere, providing data to experimenters studying specific phenomena, studying emergent events captured by MANGO imagers in the third year, presenting the results at scientific conferences, and working on manuscripts.

Science objectives of this project are to study large scale processes in the ionosphere over continental US. In the third year of this project, we used the full network of seven imagers from North Carolina to California, sampling the ionospheric airglow with 5 minute cadence during nights. These data have transformed the way we have been studying large-scale ionospheric processes. Two major discoveries of this network have been propagating waves observed in airglow from thunderstorms/hurricanes and extensive mid-latitude impact observed in the ionospheric F-region (which is between ~200-350km) airglow from geomagnetic storms.

A large fraction of geomagnetic storm related research in geospace community focuses on high latitudes as it overlaps with the auroral region. However, geomagnetic storms impact sub-auroral and mid-latitudes in several ways as well. Four major impacts that the MANGO network has observed are: 

a) low latitude aurora along with a stable auroral red (SAR) arc that is often more dynamic than stable, often occurs during a geomagnetic storm?s main phase rather than recovery phase, and has the signature of sub-auroral polarization streams along with the SAR arc, 

b) several instances of periodic wave trains propagating towards auroral zone at mid-latitude, 

c) large-scale traveling ionospheric disturbances associated with possible substorm onset at high latitudes, and 

d) airglow depletions that are east-west elongated, moving westward with finger-line structures developing northward. Most recently unusual extending east-west aligned structures were observed during the Memorial Day 2017 geomagnetic storm.

Major Outcomes:

1. While MANGO network was originally conceived to investigate primarily the lower atmospheric drivers for observed wave phenomena in the ionospheric F-region, the observations made during geomagnetically active events have inspired the investigations on storm-time impact at mid-latitudes. The large-scale TIDs generated during auroral events as observed by the MANGO network led to a study of drivers of LSTIDs using THEMIS data, MANGO data and GPS TEC data. We published results from this investigation in the Journal of Geophysical Research: Space Physics.

2. A group of atmosphere-ionosphere modelers at Embry-Riddle University used the MANGO data to validate their model showing how the traveling waves from thunderstorms generated in Kansas could be observed in the ionosphere above Iowa. A manuscript detailing this result has been submitted for publishing to Geophysical Research Letters.  

3. The ability to fetch and plot image data from the MANGO network was incorporated into the NSF EarthCube and CSSI supported Integrated Geoscience Observatory (InGeO) platform, and a Python library for fetching and visualizing MANGO data was developed under an open-source license.

4. This project has provided professional development opportunities for undergraduate students during the first year of its operation. We continue to utilize the code development done by two groups of undergraduate students for this project that was undertaken in year 1 of this award.

5. Both the PI and Co-PI of MANGO have been women scientists, with the PI being an early career woman of color. Another early career female scientist at SRI worked on developing MANGOpy Python library to incorporate and visualize MANGO data onto the InGeO platform, thereby gaining significant experience in working with imager data.
